Now granted there was a sort of an assumption that stated in that case and I maintain that it's not a valid assumption that you can never have two common carriers by railroad working together.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, what does Pacific Fruit Express carry by rail?

turn.speaker: arne_werchick
turn.label: Mr. Arne Werchick
turn.text: Among other things, they carry three million tons of ice every year.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: On rail?

turn.speaker: arne_werchick
turn.label: Mr. Arne Werchick
turn.text: They use for their own purposes.Yes, and they load and unload it at their yards and --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And how many miles of track do they have?

turn.speaker: arne_werchick
turn.label: Mr. Arne Werchick
turn.text: That's not in the record, enough to fill up one and a half square miles in Roseville anyway.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: One and a half square miles of rail?

turn.speaker: arne_werchick
turn.label: Mr. Arne Werchick
turn.text: We know that there's an -- there's rail running back and forth and I could only guess --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: So that's (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: arne_werchick
turn.label: Mr. Arne Werchick
turn.text: -- how much rail there is at Roseville alone.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: That makes them a carrier by rail.

turn.speaker: arne_werchick
turn.label: Mr. Arne Werchick
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Pacific Express.

turn.speaker: arne_werchick
turn.label: Mr. Arne Werchick
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

On the same sense that the Lone Star Steel Company with only rail inside its own plant or a terminal company that only has a railroad station where it washes the railroad car or the Union Stockyard Company which does nothing but unload beef is a common carrier by rail.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: The terminal does more than wash cars.
It moves cars, box them up, switches them.
The individual employee was injured while the car was being washed, but it was no question that the terminal railroad was a railroad.

turn.speaker: arne_werchick
turn.label: Mr. Arne Werchick
turn.text: Again I can only --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Is that right?

turn.speaker: arne_werchick
turn.label: Mr. Arne Werchick
turn.text: I -- not as I read the McCullough decision in that particular instance.
And also the McCabe versus Boston Terminal where they had no tracks of their own -- I mean no engines of their own, no cars of their own.
They merely gave signals to the engineer to move the car one way or another.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: What's the difference between a fruit expressed car and Pullman car insofar as being moved by rail?

turn.speaker: arne_werchick
turn.label: Mr. Arne Werchick
turn.text: I think they're both carriers in the transportation service by rail.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Oh, then you disagree with the Pullman case?

turn.speaker: arne_werchick
turn.label: Mr. Arne Werchick
turn.text: Robin -- with the Robinson case?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: arne_werchick
turn.label: Mr. Arne Werchick
turn.text: Insofar as it might be assumed to hold that, yes.
Although it can be distinguished as an agency or joint employment case, it doesn't have to be reached.
Certainly I feel that that is definitely carriage and transportation.

And I feel that Mr. Willis in the general counsel for Pullman in testifying before Congress in 1939 so stated but then made an artificial distinction that they weren't a common carrier even though the ICC classifies them as a transportation agency, yes sir.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Werchick, if we decide with you, do we wipe out the protection of all these 4,000 employees under the Workman's Compensation Acts of all the states of the Union?

turn.speaker: arne_werchick
turn.label: Mr. Arne Werchick
turn.text: Yes Mr. Chief Justice, but you bring them within the federal social legislation that covers this railroad industry in terms of pension benefits --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I was just --

turn.speaker: arne_werchick
turn.label: Mr. Arne Werchick
turn.text: -- and injury benefits --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I was just asking if that is a--

turn.speaker: arne_werchick
turn.label: Mr. Arne Werchick
turn.text: -- but yes.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- is the alternative.

turn.speaker: arne_werchick
turn.label: Mr. Arne Werchick
turn.text: Yes, that's the alternative to workman's compensation.
